utterances: And so it's a faulty comparison, and I don't know if he thought he was going to strike a nerve with black folk around the world or people of color around the world, but it was really ridiculous.
I think, actually, it was a very smart move.
I think it got him on the front pages for a period of time.
I don't think that al-Qaeda's issue was with George Bush per say.
I think al-Qaeda was able to make an issue with George Bush because so many people had a problem with George Bush.
When you look at the statements that they've made about why they're doing what they're doing, it isn't tied to any particular administration or president.
It has to do with a fundamental issue about how the United States interacts with the Arab world and their vision of the Caliphate.

When we look ahead to the foreign policy issues affecting this presidency that we have coming up, many people have said that, you know, the issues are going to hit pretty quick of how you balance the promise to get out of the war in 16 months with the promise to now create tens of millions of new jobs.
Those are both two very deep promises, and they're not necessarily in opposition, but they may be in opposition in terms of how much time the president can spend on them.
And they would both radically transform the society at present.
Yeah, absolutely.
So, well, I'm going to go to you, Shaun.
Do you think that there are going to be issues in dealing with these issues of foreign security, including terrorism, and then dealing with the economy at home?
Absolutely.

I mean, it's going to be tough, but I think what Obama is doing, and I even see today the markets are going up, they went up on Friday, he's trying to put the best, most capable people, people that do have big egos, big leadership quotas, he's trying to put the right people in the right places to, kind of, manage the economy, to manage national security, to manage foreign affairs.
So he's bringing the right people to the table.
There's so much for him to do, he knows he can't do it all by himself.
And so I think he's bringing, from either Jim Jones with national security or today we say Geithner and Larry Summers and others dealing with the economy.
This is not something that one man could do by himself.

And so I think people are starting to feel at least a little more comfortable knowing that you may have someone like Hillary Clinton and Bill Clinton, who have great world travel - and they do come as a team, whether we like it or not, dealing with international relations.
So Obama is picking the right people to be in leadership, and so he's definitely going to have to manage all of these things.
It's going to be difficult, but I'm encouraged.
All right, guys.
We need you to stay with us.
We're going to take a break and come back and talk a little bit about Saxby Chambliss and a race there - the question of whether or not black folks will turn out.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'm Farai Chideya, and this is News & Notes.
We're back with our Bloggers' Roundtable.

With us today we've got Shaun King of the blog Shaun in the City, Kimberly Coleman who blogs at SistaGirlSpeaksUp.blogspot.com, and Harry Allen, who maintains the blog Media Assassin at HarryAllen.info.
So guys, I'm going to pop right back into the politics, domestic politics this time.
The U.S.
Senate race between Republican Saxby Chambliss and Democrat Jim Martin in Georgia is going to a runoff.
The incumbent, Chambliss, didn't get 50 percent of the vote.
Now, African Americans turned out in large numbers to vote early for the presidential race, but this could be a case of much lower black turnout.
Democrats are just two seats shy of the 60-seat filibuster-proof majority, and some say a visit by President-elect Obama is the only way to recreate the base turnout on November 4th.
Kimberly, how do you see this shaking out, particularly with the black vote?
This is one of the things that concerned me in the election, that if Barack Obama didn't win, how would the Democratic Party rejuvenate the black vote and the youth vote and the new voters?
Well, now we see that they're going to have to do that a little sooner than the mid-year elections two years from now.
I think that Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton and Bill Clinton should return to Georgia to rejuvenate that black vote.
I think that a visit, if the seat is worth it to him, especially if Al Franken wins in Minnesota over the incumbent Norm Coleman, to get that 60 votes.
If it is that important to him.
Some people say that he doesn't want to make that trip to, you know, risk his reputation in case there is a Democratic loss.
Shaun, you're in Atlanta.
What do you think Barack Obama hasn't had, perhaps, as much traction in Georgia to begin with?
Well, Barack Obama's got great traction in Georgia, actually.
I mean, I know he didn't win the state, but it was a very narrow loss.
I mean, it really surprised me that it was as close as it was.
I understand the argument that people want him to come here, but I find it very unlikely that Jim Martin's going to win that race.
If Jim Martin lost with all of the black vote, it's going to be very, very difficult for him win.
But the truth is that turnout is low on both sides of the aisle.
I mean, people here in Georgia really have political fatigue right now.
I mean, the commercials are going non-stop, and so people are really turned off, I think, by the race altogether.
And I think Barack Obama also doesn't want to lower himself and kind of get into this very messy political fray.
And even like Kim said, and then come here and campaign for someone that may lose.
The truth is, though, that I think the Democrats really already have a de facto 60-person vote in the Senate.
There are several very moderate and even kind of left-leaning Republicans in the Senate that are going to give them that 60-vote filibuster with some tough issues.
Harry, do you feel as secure about whether or not the Democrats have a filibuster-proof majority?
Well, I think the thing that this really makes clear is that what we just saw, the race before, November 4th, was not about Democrats or Republicans, it was about Barack Obama.
Barack Obama was the new brand, so to speak.
And I think this also raises a question about the ongoing queries as to what Barack Obama's going to do with this incredible infrastructure that he developed to win.
Like is that going to be put in some way to new uses, or to uses like this?
All right.
I want to move on to something that I'm sure you have plenty to say on, all of you.
But you know, all right, I'm going to start with you, Harry Allen, Media Assassin.
You've worked in the past with a lot of folks in hip-hop, but particularly my favorites, Public Enemy.
Now, the Philadelphia hip-hop band The Roots is going into semi-retirement.
They are reportedly going to be the house band for comedian Jimmy Fallon when he takes on Conan O'Brien's late-night talk show.
The Roots are known for hits like ""You Got Me,"" featuring Erykah Badu and ""What They Do."" Harry, if this is true, is this a good move for The Roots?
I think it's a great move for The Roots.
I've known the members and written about them and reviewed their records for years.
I met Ahmir before the band was really well-known at all, and we've maintained a good relationship.
And I couldn't think of anything better than being on TV every single night in terms of increasing ones visibility and the knowledge about one's name and of one's music.
And I think that they're going to do incredible work, and if this is actually going to take place, I think it's a great choice and a very smart one that Jimmy Fallon is making.
But Kimberly...
Absolutely.
Let me get Kimberly here for a second.

I mean, do you think, though, that this is, you know, now that you can hear, for example, the Buzzcocks in a car commercial and people who like punk rock and people who like new wave will hear those songs all the time.
Is this in a way - do you have mixed feelings about them becoming a house band, as opposed to being one of these stalwarts who really have fought the music industry hard to be themselves?
No, I think it's excellent.
When I first read it, I thought back to, you know, when I first listened to ""Rapper's Delight,"" and I remember being in the car and, you know, my mother said, this will never last, you know.
And now, you know, many years later - it's the only thing my mother's probably been wrong on, by the way.
But it's...
That's a nice thing to say.
But, I mean, just thinking back to that and seeing even Sugarhill Gang on D.L.
Hughley's show a couple years ago.
I think it's great.
I think it really puts, you know, hip-hop in the forefront again.
Although, that show is a little bit past my bedtime, I'll be so inclined to tape it or Tivo it, as it were, if it is true.
Shaun, everyone else is excited.
What about you?
Well, you know, when you said mixed feelings, I hadn't really thought of it like that, but I hear you.
I wish The Roots were selling out stadiums all across the country.
Everybody knows that they're that gifted and talented and skilled and unique.
But considering the turnout and the reception that they get, this is a phenomenal opportunity.
I hope this boosts their career.
You know, I don't see it as a step down.
I mean, it's a great opportunity.
I mean, like Harry said, being on TV every night, increasing your visibility to a national audience.
Jimmy's really popular, so his show may do well, and I know he's going to really feature The Roots prominently.
So I mean, it could be a great opportunity, but I don't see it as like their having to lower themselves to do this.
I mean, this is a good opportunity for them, and hopefully more people will be turned onto what they're doing.
Yeah, they're going to definitely transform the position as opposed to having the position transform them.
Yeah, true.
I always thought it would have been a good idea if Dave Chappelle had done that.
I mean, I know he had different, you know, people from The Roots on, especially the drummer.
But I always thought that would have been a really good idea to like end his show, you know, with The Roots on there.
Well it's funny.
It makes me think of the Chris Rock Show back when he had a variety show.
Music was a huge part of that.
So...
He had Grand Master Flash as his band.
Yes, yes.
It was a DJ Grand Master Flash, one of the legends.
But having a band on in this capacity, it sounds like you're all for it.
Yeah.
It's great exposure for them.
These guys are super talented, just super talented and super creative and super imaginative.
So it's going to be really just something to see, I think.
All right.
On that note, thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you, Farai.

We were talking to Shaun King from the blog Shaun in the City, he joined us from Georgia Public Broadcasting in Atlanta, Kimberly Coleman who blogs at SistaGirlSpeaksup.blogspot.com, she joined us from NPR's headquarters in Washington, D.C., and Harry Allen, who maintains the blog Media Assassin at HarryAllen.info.
He joined us from NPR studios in New York.
The government of Austria is in chaos.
It started with a leaked video that appears to show the country's vice chancellor promising government contracts to a Russian woman.
In exchange, she would buy stakes in an Austrian newspaper and use it to support the vice chancellor's party.
That party would be the far-right Freedom Party founded by former Nazis after World War II.
Until today, it was part of Austria's ruling coalition.
Now the vice chancellor is out, and so are all the other Freedom Party ministers.
To tell us more about what this means for Austria and for Europe, we're joined from Vienna by Valerie Hopkins of the Financial Times.
Hey, Valerie.
Hi.
Thanks for having me.
Glad to have you with us.
So lay out in as succinct a timeline as you can - but how did we get from this one scandalous video to now five government officials having to vacate their posts?
